Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, cream the butter and brown sugar together on medium-high speed, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and vanilla extract and beat until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Mixture may appear curdled and that\u2019s ok.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, graham cracker crumbs, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Pour the flour mixture into the wet ingredients and then beat on medium speed until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Press/spread 2/3 of the graham cookie dough into prepared pan. (Doesn&#8217;t have to be exact, just eyeball it.) It will be a thin layer and the dough is sticky, so use your hands if needed. Spread the marshmallow creme evenly on top. This will be tricky since the marshmallow creme is sticky, but do the best you can to get an even layer. Layer chocolate chips evenly on top. Mold the remaining cookie dough into flat pieces and layer on top of the chocolate chips, as pictured and shown in the video above. You won&#8217;t have enough dough to make one single layer, so some chocolate chips/marshmallow will be exposed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/smore-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the bars for 25-30 minutes or until the top is lightly golden brown. leveled)", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/4 cup (56g) unrefined coconut oil, solid (not melted or liquid)", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "3 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon coconut extract", "1/2 cup (120g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120ml) canned coconut milk, at room temperature*", "3/4 cup (60g) sweetened shredded coconut", "salted caramel for filling, cooled for 30 minutes*", "chocolate buttercream frosting for topping", "optional: toasted coconut for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line a 12-count muffin pan with cupcake liners. Line a second pan with 3-4 liners\u2014this recipe makes about 15-16 cupcakes. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-caramel-coconut-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make\u00a0the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-caramel-coconut-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and solid coconut oil together on high speed until smooth and creamy\u2014about 1 minute. Add the sugar and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the egg whites, vanilla extract, and coconut extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the sour cream. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the coconut milk and shredded coconut until combined. Do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no large lumps stuck at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick with a few lumps of shredded coconut.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-caramel-coconut-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides. Bake for 19-22 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Allow cupcakes to cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then remove from the pan to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-caramel-coconut-cupcakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a sharp knife, cut a circle/hole into the center of the cooled cupcake to create a little pocket about 1 inch deep. This piece you removed will be the shape of a cone. Set it aside. Place about 1 teaspoon of caramel inside the cupcake\u2014or however much will fit. Slice off the pointy end of the &#8220;cone&#8221; piece of cupcake you removed so that it can fit on top of the filling. Repeat with all cupcakes. See my How to Fill Cupcakes post if you need extra visuals or help with this step.", "name": "Fill the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-caramel-coconut-cupcakes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare frosting and frost cooled cupcakes.\u00a0I used the Wilton #12 round piping tip. Grease a 9-inch or 10-inch springform pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and 3/4 cup granulated sugar together on high speed until creamy and combined, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) On medium speed, add 1 egg at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in the vanilla extract and sour cream. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Turn the mixer on low speed and beat until completely combined. Using a rubber spatula or wooden spoon, fold in the blackberries. Batter is thick.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the batter into the prepared pan. Spoon and spread over cake batter. It&#8217;s a thick cream cheese topping, so do your best to spread around\u2014doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the brown sugar, flour, and cinnamon together in a medium bowl. Cut in the cold butter with a pastry blender or a fork (or even with your hands) until the mixture resembles pea-sized crumbs. Sprinkle evenly over cream cheese layer.", "name": "Make the crumb topping:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cake for 60-65 minutes or until it no longer jiggles in the center. A toothpick inserted in the center should come out *mostly* clean. (A few moist crumbs are fine.) Halfway during bake time (about 30 minutes), tent a piece of aluminum foil over the cake to help prevent over-browning around the edges.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool cake for at least 30 minutes before removing the sides of the springform pan and slicing and serving. During this time, you can make the icing by whisking the icing ingredients together until smooth. Add more milk/cream/lemon juice to thin out if needed. Drizzle icing over cake while it&#8217;s still warm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cake at room temperature for up to 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blackberry-cream-cheese-crumb-cake/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT1H5M", "totalTime": "PT2H5M", "recipeYield": ["10", "serves 10"], "recipeCategory": "Cake", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "36", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Blackberry Cream Cheese Crumb Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This blackberry crumb cake features a blackberry-studded buttery breakfast cake, smooth cream cheese layer, and cinnamon brown sugar crumble topping. Once boiling, reduce to medium heat and allow to simmer until reduced down to 2/3 cup, about 20 minutes. Set 1/2 cup aside to cool for 10\u201315 minutes before using in the cupcake batter. While it&#8217;s warm, mix the rest of the reduced Guinness (about 2\u20132.5 Tablespoons) with the 2 teaspoons of espresso powder used in the frosting. Set this mixture aside for step 5. You can do this step 1 day ahead of time if needed. Refrigerate overnight. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add the 1/2 cup (120ml) reduced Guinness, then whisk until *just* combined. Do not over-mix. The batter will be on the thinner side.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/guinness-chocolate-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour or spoon the batter into the liners. Fill each 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides or sinking. Bake for 19\u201322 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Don&#8217;t over-bake, which will dry out the cupcakes. Begin checking for doneness at 19 minutes. For around 36 mini cupcakes, bake for about 11\u201313 minutes, same oven temperature. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar, cocoa powder, milk, reduced Guinness/espresso powder mixture, milk, and vanilla extract. Beat on low for 30 seconds then increase to high speed and beat until combined and creamy. Taste. Add a pinch of salt if desired. (I always add 1/8 teaspoon.) Add up to 1/2 cup more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-buttercream-frosting/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover tightly and store for up to 1 week in the refrigerator or up to 3 months in the freezer. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "lemon blueberry scones", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/lemon-blueberry-scones-lemon-glaze-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/lemon-blueberry-scones-lemon-glaze-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/lemon-blueberry-scones-lemon-glaze-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/lemon-blueberry-scones-lemon-glaze.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-lemon-blueberry-scones/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and work surface", "6 Tablespoons (75g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon fresh\u00a0lemon zest", "2 and 1/2 teaspoons\u00a0baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, frozen", "1/2 cup + 1 Tablespoon (135g/ml) heavy cream, cold and divided", "1 large egg, cold", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 heaping cup (140g) fresh blueberries\u00a0", "1 Tablespoon (15g/ml) water", "optional for topping: coarse sugar", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217;\u00a0sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45g/ml) fresh lemon juice"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, lemon zest, baking powder, and salt. Using the large holes of a box grater, shred the frozen butter. Add the butter to the flour mixture and use a pastry cutter, two forks, or your fingers to blend until the mixture comes together in pea-sized crumbs. Place the bowl in the freezer before you continue.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-lemon-blueberry-scones/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl or liquid measuring cup, whisk together 1/2 cup (120g/ml) of the heavy cream, the egg, and vanilla extract. Remove the flour mixture from the freezer. Drizzle the cream mixture over the flour mixture and add the blueberries. Gently mix together with a spatula or wooden spoon until everything appears moistened and the ingredients are just combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-lemon-blueberry-scones/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly flour a work surface. Pour the crumbly mixture onto the surface and, with floured hands, work the dough into a ball as best you can. The dough should be sticky and shaggy. If it&#8217;s too sticky, sprinkle a little more flour on top. Press the dough into an 8-inch disc, about 1 inch thick. Use a sharp knife or a bench scraper to cut the disc into 8 wedges.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-lemon-blueberry-scones/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, mix the remaining 1 Tablespoon cream with the water, then brush it on the scones. For extra sweetness and a little crunch, sprinkle the tops with coarse sugar. (You can do this before or after refrigerating in the next step.) Place the scones on a plate or a parchment paper-lined baking sheet and refrigerate for at least 15 minutes or up to 24 hours. (If refrigerating for more than an hour, lightly cover the scones.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-lemon-blueberry-scones/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar then beat on medium-high speed until creamy and combined. The cookie dough will be thick and a little crumbly.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-spice-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the cookie dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for 30 minutes and up to 3 days. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Croissant Bread (Loaf)", "description": "Bakers of any skill level can use this thoroughly detailed recipe to make a beautifully flaky and golden brown loaf of homemade croissant bread. There are 3 rounds of 20-minute refrigerations. Do not break up the lamination steps and do not extend the refrigeration times because the dough will begin to over-expand.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Croissant Bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/croissant-bread-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/croissant-bread-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/croissant-bread-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/croissant-bread-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup\u00a0(240ml)\u00a0whole milk, warmed to about\u00a0110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0instant\u00a0or\u00a0active dry yeast\u00a0(1 standard packet, see Notes)", "3 Tablespoons (38g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 and 1/4 teaspoons salt", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted or salted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 3 equal pieces", "3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed and for lamination", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) salted butter, slightly softened (see Notes)", "1 large egg, cold or room temperature", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) water"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch the video tutorial and use the step-by-step photos before you begin. Read the recipe instructions and notes before beginning. Make room in the refrigerator for your half baking sheet for steps 6\u20139.", "name": "Preliminary notes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the salt, butter, and 2 cups (250g) of flour. Beat on medium speed for 2 minutes, stopping and scraping down the bowl as needed to help the mixture combine. There may still be chunks of butter\u2014that&#8217;s ok. Add remaining flour, scrape down the bowl as needed, and beat on low speed until a soft dough forms and pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Dough will be very soft, but not overly sticky. Beat in 2\u20133 more Tablespoons of flour if dough seems very sticky. Avoid adding more flour than you need.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "1st rise", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides of the dough in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1.5\u20132 hours or until nearly double in size. (For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a silicone baking mat-lined, parchment paper-lined, or lightly floured baking sheet. (I highly recommend a silicone baking mat because you can roll the dough out in the next steps directly on top and it won\u2019t slide all over the counter.) Gently flatten the dough out into a 10&#215;14-inch (25x35cm) rectangle using lightly floured hands to carefully stretch, but not tear, the dough. Lightly cover and place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator, and allow the covered dough to rest and chill for 20 minutes. Do not extend this time.", "name": "Flatten dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the salted butter into 1/4-inch thick slices and, as explained in the recipe note below, make sure the butter is not overly soft. It&#8217;s important to note the following 4 tips before you begin laminating in steps 8, 9, &amp; 10: (1) It&#8217;s OK if there are air bubbles in the dough because your rolling pin will pop them. (2) If the dough tears and butter is exposed, just sprinkle the exposed butter with flour. (3) If the dough is impossible to roll, try flipping it over. If it&#8217;s still impossible to roll, cover and let it rest for 5 minutes before trying again, to let the gluten relax. And (4) Do not extend the refrigeration times, because the folded dough will begin to over-expand.\u00a0", "name": "Meanwhile, prepare for lamination", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-7"}]}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "on-step-8\">1st lamination", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the refrigerator and set baking sheet aside. I like to keep the dough on the silicone baking mat when I\u2019m rolling it because the mat is nonstick. Working with the longer (14-inch) edge in front of you, line butter down the center of the dough, covering the center third of the dough. Fold one dough edge over on top of butter, and fold other edge on top of that (like folding a business letter). Pinch/seal the two short ends to enclose butter inside. Rotate dough so the long edge is horizontally in front of you. Lightly flour the top of the folded dough and, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out to a 9&#215;12-inch (23x30cm) rectangle. Fold dough edges over on top like folding a business letter. Cover dough, place back on baking sheet, and refrigerate 20 minutes. Do not extend this time.", "name": "1st lamination", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the refrigerator and set baking sheet aside. Rotate dough so the long edge is horizontally in front of you. Lightly flour the top of the folded dough and, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out to a 9&#215;12-inch rectangle. Fold dough edges over on top like folding a business letter. Rotate dough horizontally and repeat rolling out to 9&#215;12 inches and folding like a business letter. Cover dough, place back on baking sheet, and refrigerate 20 minutes. Do not extend this time.\u00a0", "name": "2nd &amp; 3rd laminations", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the refrigerator and set baking sheet aside. Rotate dough so the long edge is horizontally in front of you. Lightly flour the top of the folded dough and using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out to a 9&#215;12-inch rectangle. Fold dough edges over on top like folding a business letter. For the last time, rotate horizontally and roll out to 9&#215;12 inches. Working from a 9-inch side, roll dough up like you would roll up a jelly roll cake or cinnamon rolls. Place 9-inch log on a cutting board and cut into 5 even rolls (just eyeball it, they don&#8217;t need to be perfectly even).", "name": "Final lamination &amp; shaping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9&#215;5-inch (23x13cm) loaf pan. Place rolls, seam side down, in loaf pan. Cover tightly and allow to rise until slightly puffy, about 45\u201360 minutes.", "name": "2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk egg wash ingredients together. Generously brush risen rolls/loaf with egg wash. Bake loaf for 1 hour until golden brown on top, loosely tenting with aluminum foil after 25 minutes to prevent the top from over-browning before the center can cook. For an accurate test of doneness, the bread is done when an instant-read thermometer reads the center of the loaf as 195\u00b0F (90\u00b0C). (Tip:\u00a0Keep in mind that the bread will continue to cook for a few minutes as it cools.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and place loaf pan on a wire rack. Cool for 30 minutes in the loaf pan. Run a knife around the edges of the pan to release the bread, and then remove bread from loaf pan and cool at least 15 more minutes directly on a wire rack before slicing and serving. (Bread tends to fall apart when sliced warm.) Bread may slightly deflate as it cools.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-14"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover croissant bread covered at room temperature for up to 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. You can also freeze it for up to 3 months and then thaw on the counter or overnight in the refrigerator. Warm up to your liking.", "name": "Storing &amp; freezing baked bread", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/#instruction-step-18"}]}], "prepTime": "PT4H45M", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT6H30M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "205", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Croissant Bread | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This video shows the process of making a deliciously flaky and buttery homemade laminated croissant bread using a simple 6 ingredient dough.\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/croissant-bread/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #croissantbread\n\n\u2022 More of Sally's baking recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT6M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/tXLb5Q1taKk?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tXLb5Q1taKk", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/tXLb5Q1taKk/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2022-03-31T20:29:18+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Nora"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-02", "reviewBody": "Loved the end result! Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Spoon the \u00a0cold filling into the crust and discard the leftover juices in the bottom of the bowl, if any. Flute or crimp the pie crust edges. Add the vanilla and beat on high until combined.\u00a0Add the flour mixture to the wet ingredients and mix on low-medium speed until just combined. Add the chocolate chips, sprinkles, and crushed Oreos. Mix on low until the add-ins are evenly disbursed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cake-batter-oreo-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate dough for at least 2 hours, or up to 3 days. This step is mandatory. The dough is fairly sticky, so chilling the dough is required in order to avoid the cookies from spreading too much. If you chill longer than 2 hours, make sure you roll the cookie dough into balls after the 2 hour mark. Place dough balls on a plate, cover tightly, and store in the refrigerator until ready to bake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cake-batter-oreo-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Use about 2 Tablespoons of cookie dough per cookie. Shape your cookie dough balls to be &#8220;taller&#8221; than they are wide, as explained and pictured in my cake batter chocolate chip cookies recipe. Press a few chocolate chips or crushed Oreo pieces into the tops of the cookie dough balls, if desired. That makes a pretty cookie. Make sure to keep dough chilled when working in batches.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cake-batter-oreo-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 10-12 minutes until edges are slightly browned. The Hug should flatten out when you press the candy corn on it. If it is not flattening out, place the pretzel hugs back in the oven for 30 more seconds.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/candy-corn-pretzel-hugs/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the pretzel hugs cool completely and let the chocolate set for about 10 minutes in the refrigerator.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/candy-corn-pretzel-hugs/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT4M", "totalTime": "PT20M", "recipeYield": "24", "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "1", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Deb"}, "datePublished": "2020-10-28", "reviewBody": "I made a comment on these way back in 2013 when my kids were still teens!  We haven't made them every year, but I'm making them again in the next day or so for both \"kids\" - youngest now a senior in college.  There was some discussion of finding the round pretzels, but the \"tiny twists\" type made by Rold Gold and Snyder's for instance work just fine.  Also I notice this year Target has some very cute round-ish pretzels that look like spiderwebs so that's my pick!  These or the Halloween Bark also by Sally appeared at our house almost every year - I still have the candy eyes I use for the bark.  Thank you!"}], "datePublished": "2012-10-07", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/candy-corn-pretzel-hugs/#recipe", "isPartOf": {"@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/candy-corn-pretzel-hugs/#article"}, "mainEntityOfPage": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/candy-corn-pretzel-hugs/"}]}, {"@context": "https://slickstream.com", "@graph": [{"@type": "Plugin", "version": "3.0.1"}, {"@type": "Site", "name": "Sally&#039;s Baking", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com", "description": "Trusted Recipes from a Self-Taught Baker", "atomUrl": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/feed/atom/", "rtl": false}, {"@type": "WebPage", "@id": 8766, "isFront": false, "isHome": false, "isCategory": false, "isTag": false, "isSingular": true, "date": "2012-10-07T23:41:30-04:00", "modified": "2022-04-10T09:30:35-04:00", "title": "Candy Corn Pretzel Hugs", "pageType": "post", "postType": "post", "featured_image": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Easy-Candy-Corn-Hugs.jpg", "author": "Sally McKenney", "categories": [{"@id": 66, "parent": 710, "slug": "candy", "name": "Candy", "parents": [{"@type": "CategoryParent", "@id": 710, "slug": "desserts", "name": "Desserts"}]}, {"@id": 710, "parent": 0, "slug": "desserts", "name": "Desserts", "parents": []}, {"@id": 707, "parent": 414, "slug": "halloween", "name": "Halloween", "parents": [{"@type": "CategoryParent", "@id": 414, "slug": "seasonal", "name": "Seasonal"}]}, {"@id": 851, "parent": 720, "slug": "nut-free", "name": "Nut Free", "parents": [{"@type": "CategoryParent", "@id": 720, "slug": "special-diet", "name": "Special Diet"}]}], "tags": ["candy corn", "Hershey's Kisses", "pretzels"]}]}]

Line a 12-cup muffin pan with cupcake liners. Line a second pan (or bake in batches) with 4 or 5 liners\u2014this recipe makes about 16\u201317 cupcakes. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar on medium-high speed until creamed together, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the egg whites and beat on high speed until smooth and combined, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add the sour cream and vanilla, and beat on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients and then, with the mixer on low speed, slowly pour in the milk and beat just until combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick. Fold in the chopped Oreos.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 19\u201322 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool the cupcakes in the pan set on a cooling rack for 20 minutes, then remove them from the pan and return to the rack to\u00a0cool completely before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar, heavy cream, and vanilla. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Add 1/4 cup more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Taste. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Transfer the vanilla frosting to another bowl; no need to clean the mixing bowl\u2014you&#8217;ll make the chocolate buttercream in it in the next step.", "name": "Make the vanilla buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, cocoa powder, heavy cream, and vanilla. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 1 full minute. Add 1/4 cup more confectioners&#8217; sugar or cocoa powder if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Taste. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet.", "name": "Make the chocolate buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can swipe the frostings on with an icing knife or use a piping tip. I used Ateco 829 in some of these pictured cupcakes and Ateco 849 in others! Here is how to fill a piping bag to swirl the two frostings together: Place your preferred piping tip inside the bag (with the end snipped off so that the tip fits through). Place the bag inside a very tall cup or glass and fold the excess bag over the edges of the cup. Spoon the vanilla frosting into one side of the bag, leaving a little space on the other side. Spoon the chocolate frosting into the other side of the bag. Don\u2019t worry, it doesn\u2019t have to be perfectly neat. Remove the bag from the cup and push the frosting down to the tip, squeezing out any air bubbles as needed. Twist the top of the bag and proceed with piping.\u00a0 Garnish with crushed Oreo crumbs, if desired.", "name": "Frost the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-oreo-cupcakes/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cupcakes tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. For best success, take your time and read through the recipe before starting.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "lemon blueberry tart", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/lemon-blueberry-tart-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/lemon-blueberry-tart-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/lemon-blueberry-tart-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/lemon-blueberry-tart-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 teaspoon cornstarch", "2 teaspoons lemon juice (or water)", "1 cup (140g) fresh or frozen blueberries (do not thaw)", "2 teaspoons granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted", "1/4 cup\u00a0(50g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1 cup\u00a0(125g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 (14 ounce weight) can full-fat\u00a0sweetened condensed milk", "6 Tablespoons (90ml) lemon juice (about 2 lemons)", "1 teaspoon lemon zest (1 lemon)", "1 large egg yolk", "Lemon slices, blueberries, leftover blueberry sauce, whipped cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a fork, mix the cornstarch and lemon juice together in a small bowl until the cornstarch has dissolved. Set aside. Warm the blueberries and sugar together in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir occasionally for 3 minutes, mashing the blueberries as best you can against the bottom and sides of the pan to help break them up. Stir in the cornstarch mixture. Cook for 2 more minutes as the sauce thickens, stirring and mashing the blueberries to break them up as desired. Remove sauce from heat and set aside at room temperature until step 6. Makes about 1/2 &#8211; 2/3 cup blueberry sauce and you&#8217;ll use about half for the swirl. (Reserve extra for garnish/serving.)", "name": "Blueberry Sauce", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the melted butter, sugar, vanilla extract, and salt together in a medium bowl. Add the flour and stir to completely combine. The dough will be a little greasy and very thick. Using a silicone spatula or your hands, press dough firmly into a 9-inch tart pan (no need to grease it), making sure the layer of crust is even on the bottom and all around the sides. It may seem like it won&#8217;t fit, but it will. You can use the bottom of a measuring cup to pack the crust in too, but sometimes it sticks.", "name": "Crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 15 minutes or until the edges are very lightly browned. Remove from the oven. Using a fork, poke a few holes all over the top of the warm crust (not all the way through the crust). This helps the filling stick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk all of the filling ingredients together until combined. Pour into warm crust. Stir up the blueberry sauce because it has likely thickened. It can still be warm when you use it in this step. If it&#8217;s too thick, warm it in the microwave for 5-10 seconds. Drop spoonfuls of blueberry sauce all over the top, using about half of the sauce. Reserve the rest of the sauce for serving. Using a toothpick or knife, gently swirl the sauce and filling together. Shimmy the pan back and forth 2-3 times to let the sauce and filling settle down into the crust a bit.", "name": "Filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 17-19 minutes, just until the center of the tart no longer jiggles when you give the pan a light tap. It will still be a little sticky on top. Avoid over-baking because the tart will taste rubbery. (Tip: Err on the side of under-baking because the filling also has a chance to set up in the refrigerator. You want a creamy soft filling.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove tart from the oven and place on a cooling rack. Cool completely at room temperature, then chill in the refrigerator uncovered for at least 2 hours and up to 1 day. If chilling for longer than 2 hours, cover it. After chilling, remove the sides of the tart pan if your pan has removable sides.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice and serve with optional garnishes including any leftover blueberry sauce.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftovers tightly and refrigerate for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-blueberry-tart/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8-10"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "588", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Lemon Blueberry Tart | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Cool, creamy, and refreshing lemon blueberry tart comes together with 10 ingredients. You really want it packed in tight\u2014as tight as possible. Bake for 20 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack for 1 hour, then transfer to the refrigerator to chill for 1 more hour. This helps firm up the bars which makes them stay compact. Remove bars from the pan using the overhang on the sides and cut into bars. Individually wrap each bar in plastic wrap or parchment. Store at room temperature for 1 week or in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. Makes excellent leftovers for lunch or dinner, too!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "goat cheese sun-dried tomato quiche, goat cheese spinach quiche", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Goat-Cheese-Spinach-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Quiche-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Goat-Cheese-Spinach-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Quiche-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Goat-Cheese-Spinach-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Quiche-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Goat-Cheese-Spinach-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Quiche.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/goat-cheese-spinach-sun-dried-tomato-quiche/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 recipe\u00a0homemade pie crust* (step-by-step photos included)", "1/2 teaspoon olive oil", "1 teaspoon minced garlic", "3 packed cups fresh spinach (see note about using frozen)*", "4 large eggs", "1 cup whole milk*", "1/2 cup sun-dried tomatoes, drained and chopped", "4 ounces goat cheese, crumbled or chopped", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0each\u00a0salt\u00a0and\u00a0pepper"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I like to make sure my pie dough is prepared before I begin the quiche. Make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and blind baking (next step). And here&#8217;s a time-saving tip\u2014as the crust blind bakes, you can get started on the filling which begins with step 7.", "name": "Preliminary Notes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/goat-cheese-spinach-sun-dried-tomato-quiche/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0On a floured work surface, roll out one of the disks of chilled dough (freeze the other for another time). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is completely smooth.\u00a0Chill the pie crust in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes. (And up to 5 days. Or freeze for up to 3 months. Cover the pie crust with plastic wrap if chilling for longer than 30 minutes or if you\u2019re freezing it. If you freeze it, let it thaw for a couple hours in the refrigerator before continuing.)", "name": "Partially blind bake the pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/goat-cheese-spinach-sun-dried-tomato-quiche/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the crust is chilling, preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/goat-cheese-spinach-sun-dried-tomato-quiche/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line the chilled pie crust with parchment paper or aluminum foil. (Crunch up the parchment paper first so that you can easily shape it into the crust.)\u00a0Fill with pie weights or dried beans. Bake until the edges of the crust are starting to brown, about 15-16 minutes. Remove pie from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper/aluminum foil (with the weights) out of the pie. Prick holes all around the bottom crust with a fork. Return the pie crust to the oven and bake until the bottom crust is just beginning to brown, about 7-8 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/goat-cheese-spinach-sun-dried-tomato-quiche/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove crust from the oven. "recipeIngredient": ["2 teaspoons room-temperature water, divided", "1\u00a0teaspoon\u00a0cornstarch", "1 and 1/2 cups (205g) fresh or frozen raspberries (do not thaw)", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "22 regular Oreo cookies (not Double-Stuf)", "5 Tablespoons (71g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted", "6 ounces (170g) white chocolate, finely chopped", "16 ounces (452g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1/3 cup (65g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon (8g) all-purpose flour", "1 teaspoon lemon juice", "1 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "2\u00a0large\u00a0eggs, at room temperature"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The raspberry sauce must cool down completely before using, so I recommend making it first. Mix 1 teaspoon water with 1 teaspoon cornstarch in a very small bowl. Set aside. Combine raspberries, granulated sugar, and remaining 1 teaspoon of water together in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir the mixture as it begins to cook, breaking up some of the raspberries as you stir. Once simmering, add the cornstarch mixture. Continue to stir and allow to simmer for 3 minutes. Remove the pan from heat and press through a fine mesh strainer to remove the seeds. Allow the thin raspberry sauce to cool completely before using. Cover and store for up to 1 week in the refrigerator.", "name": "Make &amp; cool the raspberry sauce", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line the bottom and sides of a 9-inch square baking pan (8-inch is too small) with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on the sides to lift the finished bars out (makes cutting easier!). Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a food processor or blender, pulse 22 Oreos (including the cream filling) into a fine crumb. You should have about 2 cups (packed) crumbs, or 250g. Pour crumbs into a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to combine. The mixture will be thick and quite wet. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into prepared pan. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom to make a compact, thick crust. Bake for 8 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside. Leave oven on.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped white chocolate in a double boiler or the microwave. If using the microwave: place the white chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. Melt in 20 second increments in the microwave, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Let the warm chocolate cool as you work on the other cheesecake filling ingredients. You can place it in the refrigerator, but just don&#8217;t let it solidify!", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the flour, lemon juice, vanilla extract, and salt, then beat until fully combined. On medium speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating after each addition until just blended. After the 2nd egg is incorporated into the batter, stop mixing. A few small lumps can remain. Pour in the cooled (but still liquid) white chocolate. Beat on low speed just until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour half of the cheesecake filling onto the crust. It&#8217;s ok if the crust is still slightly warm. Drizzle half of the raspberry sauce all over the top. Spread remaining cheesecake filling on top. (It&#8217;s ok if the raspberry sauce has spread to the sides or slightly incorporates into the top layer of cheesecake.) Drizzle remaining raspberry sauce on top, then use a toothpick or knife to gently swirl everything together.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 32\u201336 minutes or until the cheesecake appears set on top and the edges are lightly browned. The bars will be puffy, but will sink slightly down as they cool. Place pan on a wire rack. Cool for 45 minutes at room temperature, then chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours (and up to 1 day) before slicing. If you plan to chill the bars for longer, loosely cover with aluminum foil after 3 hours of chilling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-raspberry-cheesecake-bars/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "To slice, lift the bars out of the pan as a whole using the parchment overhang on the sides. sugar and/or fresh florals"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 8-inch or 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.) I recommend using nonstick spray for greasing. I also recommend 8 inch cake pans as the 9 inch cakes will be pretty thin.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the sugar and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the egg whites. Beat on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Then beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the milk until combined. Do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into cake pans. Bake for around 22-24 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it is done. Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla extract, and almond extract on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3-4 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks and are the perfect consistency for decorating cakes. Use immediately or cover tightly and chill in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours. Yields about 4 cups.", "name": "Make the whipped cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If cooled cakes are domed on top, use a large serrated knife to slice a thin layer off the tops to create a flat surface. This is called \u201cleveling\u201d the cakes. (Discard thin layer or crumble over ice cream.) Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly spread 1 heaping cup of whipped cream on top. I always use an icing spatula to spread. Arrange a single layer of mixed berries on top. Top with 2nd cake layer. Spread another 1 heaping cup of whipped cream on top, then a single layer of berries. Top with 3rd cake layer. Spread remaining whipped cream on top and garnish with fresh berries. Add a dusting of confectioners&#8217; sugar on the berries, if desired, and/or garnish with fresh florals.", "name": "Assemble cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chill the assembled cake, uncovered, for at least 2 hours and up to 1 day before slicing and serving. This time in the refrigerator helps the whipped cream thicken and makes cutting neater and easier. If chilling for longer than a few hours, you can carefully cover it with plastic wrap or use a cake carrier for storing in the refrigerator (what I always store my cakes in!). *Note that the berries could begin to release their juices if kept in the refrigerator for longer than 2 hours. For cutting, I recommend using your sharpest knife and cutting slowly.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-berry-cream-cake/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT22M", "totalTime": "PT5H30M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 servings"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "175", "ratingValue": "5"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Fresh Berry Cream Cake  | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Learn how to create a beautiful fresh berry cream cake. Begin with chocolate cupcakes, top with peanut butter frosting, and dunk into a chocolate shell coating!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "hi-hat cupcakes, peanut butter chocolate cupcakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/peanut-butter-chocolate-hi-hat-cupcakes-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/peanut-butter-chocolate-hi-hat-cupcakes-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/peanut-butter-chocolate-hi-hat-cupcakes-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/peanut-butter-chocolate-hi-hat-cupcakes-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-hi-hat-cupcakes/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 batch homemade chocolate cupcakes", "3\u00a0egg whites, room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar", "10 Tablespoons (142g) unsalted butter, very soft\u00a0(not melted)", "1 cup (250g) creamy peanut butter (not natural style)", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch salt", "10 ounces (280g) semi-sweet chocolate, coarsely chopped*", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons canola or vegetable oil"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Set the butter and eggs out that you&#8217;ll need for the frosting. By the time you bake and cool the cupcakes, the butter will be soft and the egg whites will be room temperature.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-hi-hat-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the chocolate cupcakes. Allow them to completely cool.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-hi-hat-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place egg whites, sugar, and cream of tartar in a\u00a0heatproof bowl. Set bowl over a saucepan filled with two inches of simmering water. Do not let it touch the water. (You can use a double boiler if you have one.) Whisk constantly until sugar is dissolved, about 4 minutes. You can use a candy thermometer to make sure they&#8217;re ready; it will register 160\u00b0F (71\u00b0C).2", "name": "Make the peanut butter frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-hi-hat-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the mixing bowl to an electric mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. Beat on high speed for 5-6 minutes until soft, glossy peaks form. (See photo above.) On\u00a0medium speed, add the butter 1 Tablespoon at a time until completely combined and creamy. Some tiny chunks of butter may remain; it will all smooth out. Finally, beat in the peanut butter and vanilla until combined. Taste. Add a pinch of salt if needed. I like to add 1/8 teaspoon of salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-hi-hat-cupcakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pipe frosting onto each cooled cupcake. I use a\u00a0Wilton #12 tip. You may have an extra cupcake or 2 leftover if you use a lot of frosting on each cupcake. I use\u00a0roughly\u00a01/4 cup of frosting on each.\u00a0Chill cupcakes in the refrigerator or freezer until frosting is completely firm. I freeze mine for 20 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-hi-hat-cupcakes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0melt the chopped chocolate and oil together in the microwave in 20 second increments, stirring after each until completely melted. Cupcakes came out awesome. For the frosting, I used Country Crock sticks with avocado oil (7tbsp) and 3tbsp of butter flavored shortening (I would normally never eat the stuff but limited options). Everything else stayed the same. The flavor was really on par with a regular SMBC and had a very similar texture (luscious, creamy, light) BUT it doesn't maintain the structure that real dairy gives. It's a little too soft, but not a recipe ruiner. I can't imagine Florida summers help with that, but it is what it is. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the eggs and beat on high speed for 1 minute, then beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. The mixture will be very lumpy and appear curdled\u2014that&#8217;s ok. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients. Turn the mixer to low speed and as the mixer runs, slowly pour in the milk. Beat on low speed just until all of the ingredients are combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no large lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick. Gently fold in the chocolate chips.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour and spread batter evenly into prepared loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 60-75 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. That time is a guideline\u2014all ovens differ, so keep a close eye on the cake after 55 minutes. If the cake is browning too quickly on top, loosely tent with aluminum foil as it bakes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool cake in the pan set on a wire rack for at least 1 hour before removing from the pan. Feel free to continue cooling it directly on a wire rack or slice and enjoy then. (It will still be slightly warm.) You can drizzle the topping on the cake when the cake is still slightly warm after that 1 hour of cooling or wait until the cake has cooled completely to top it.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir and melt chocolate chips and peanut butter together in a small saucepan over medium heat on the stove or in a heatproof bowl using the microwave. We usually use the microwave and melt in 30 second increments, stirring after each until smooth. Drizzle over cake. Topping sets into a fudge-like consistency after several hours.", "name": "Optional Topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftovers tightly and store cake (with or without topping) at room temperature for 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT1H5M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8-10"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "102", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Chocolate Chip Loaf Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Chocolate chip loaf cake tastes extra moist and is loaded with chocolate chips in each bite. You can use your favorite cheese in the filling. I love and usually use shredded parmesan.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pull apart bread, garlic bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/garlic-rosemary-pull-apart-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/garlic-rosemary-pull-apart-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/garlic-rosemary-pull-apart-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/garlic-rosemary-pull-apart-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star*", "1 Tablespoon granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (180ml)\u00a0whole milk", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 large egg", "2 and 1/3 cups (291g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed*", "1 teaspoon salt", "1 teaspoon garlic powder", "1 Tablespoon finely chopped fresh rosemary (or 2 teaspoons dried)", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, extra soft (see note)", "1 Tablespoon finely chopped fresh rosemary (or 2 teaspoons dried)", "1 Tablespoon finely chopped fresh parsley (or 2 teaspoons dried)", "2\u00a0garlic cloves, minced or\u00a01/2 teaspoon\u00a0garlic powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (95g) shredded parmesan, mozzarella, or white cheddar cheese (or your favorite shredded cheese)", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter, melted", "coarse or flaky sea salt for sprinkling"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Place the yeast and sugar in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Or, if you do not own a stand mixer, a regular large mixing bowl. Heat the milk on the stove or in the microwave until warm to touch, about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C). Pour warm milk on top of yeast/sugar. Whisk gently to combine, then loosely cover with a clean kitchen towel and allow to sit for 5-10 minutes. The mixture will be frothy after 5-10 minutes.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter, egg, flour, salt, garlic powder, and rosemary. Beat on low speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 3 minutes. If the dough isn&#8217;t pulling away from the sides of the bowl, add a little more flour, a Tablespoon at a time. Dough will be soft.\u00a0", "name": "If you do not have a mixer, you can mix the dough together with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula in this step", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 Tablespoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Shape the kneaded dough into a ball. Place the dough in a greased bowl (I use nonstick spray to grease) and cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place in a slightly warm environment to rise until doubled in size, around 60-90 minutes. (If desired, use my warm oven trick for rising. See my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the dough rises, prepare the filling in the next step and grease a 9&#215;5-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, mix the soft butter, rosemary, parsley, garlic, and salt together. If the butter is soft enough, you can just mix it all together with a spoon or fork. You can use an electric mixer if that&#8217;s easier too. Cover tightly and set aside until ready to use. (Don&#8217;t refrigerate unless making well in advance. It&#8217;s easiest to spread on the dough when at room temperature. If refrigerated, let it come to room temperature before spreading on dough pieces.)", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface. Divide it into 12 equal pieces, each about 1/4 cup of dough and a little larger than a golf ball. Using lightly floured hands, flatten each into a circle that&#8217;s about 4 inches in diameter. The circle doesn&#8217;t have to be perfectly round. I do not use a rolling pan to flatten, but you certainly can if you want. Spread 1-2 teaspoons of filling mixture onto each. Sprinkle each with 1 Tablespoon of cheese. Fold circles in half and line in prepared baking pan, round side up. See photos above for a visual.", "name": "Assemble the bread:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "truction-step-8\">2nd Rise", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover\u00a0with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and allow to rise once again in a slightly warm environment until puffy, about 45 minutes.", "name": "2nd Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position then preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake until golden brown, about 50 minutes. If you find the top of the loaf is browning too quickly, tent with aluminum foil. (Don&#8217;t be alarmed if there&#8217;s melted butter around the sides of the bread as it bakes, it will seep into the bread before it finishes.) Remove from the oven and place the pan on a wire rack. If desired, brush with melted butter for topping and sprinkle with sea salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool for 10 minutes in the pan, then remove from the pan and serve warm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftovers at room temperature for up to 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. Since the bread is extra crispy on the exterior, it will become a little hard after day 1. Reheat in a 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C) oven for 10-15 minutes until interior is soft again or warm in the microwave.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/rosemary-garlic-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-12"}]}], "prepTime": "PT3H", "cookTime": "PT50M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "185", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Rosemary Garlic Pull Apart Bread | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Here's how to make a flavorful pull apart bread using a simple 9 ingredient rosemary-infused yeasted dough. Add the granulated sugar and brown sugar and beat on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color. Beat in egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. On high speed, beat in the Biscoff spread until completely combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/biscoff-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl,\u00a0whisk the\u00a0flour, baking soda, cornstarch, cinnamon, and salt together until combined. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. Switch to high speed and beat in the chocolate chips. The cookie dough will be a little sticky. Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough. I always chill mine overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/biscoff-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 20 minutes. If the cookie dough chilled longer than 3 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes. This makes the cookie dough easier to scoop and roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/biscoff-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/biscoff-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop and roll balls of dough, about 1.5 Tablespoons of dough each, into balls and place on the baking sheets. (I like using a\u00a0medium cookie scoop\u00a0for this.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/biscoff-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 9-10 minutes. Be sure to rotate the pan once or twice during bake time. The baked cookies will look extremely soft in the centers when you remove them from the oven; they will continue to &#8220;set&#8221; as they cool. Allow to cool for 5 minutes on the cookie sheet. Transfer to cooling rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/biscoff-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT3H15M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["20", "20 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "27", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "John"}, "datePublished": "2025-01-31", "reviewBody": "Best thing ever!  Made them almost twice the size and adding about two minutes was ideal.  Thicker, more delicious center with the bigger size.  I learned a tip with egg portioning for these times with large eggs tending to run as jumbo and that is to base a whole large egg out of shell at 50 grams. I partially beat it and carefully discard any amount over 50 grams to achieve the equivalent size of a large.  Other cookie recipes were spreading too much until I figured out the eggs were too big.  \r\nAs far as when yolks only are required, no adjustment seems necessary.  I hope this all helps anyone."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jenna"}, "datePublished": "2025-06-28", "reviewBody": "When I tell you these are the best cookies I've ever had and people go absolutely nuts over them.
