My trick is to whip the egg whites, which guarantees a smooth velvet crumb.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Red Velvet Cake with Cream Cheese Frosting", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/red-velvet-cake-slice-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/red-velvet-cake-slice-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/red-velvet-cake-slice-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/red-velvet-cake-slice-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups (360g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "2 Tablespoons (10g) unsweetened natural cocoa powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2\u00a0cups (400g) granulated sugar", "1 cup (240ml) canola or vegetable oil", "4 large eggs, room temperature and separated", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon distilled white vinegar", "liquid or gel red food coloring", "1 cup (240ml) buttermilk, at room temperature", "16 ounces (452g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "5 cups (600g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "pinch of salt, to taste"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease two 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour,\u00a0baking soda, cocoa powder, and salt together in a large\u00a0bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make\u00a0the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the oil, egg yolks, vanilla extract, and vinegar and beat on high for 2 minutes. (Set the egg whites aside.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients in 2-3 additions alternating with the buttermilk. Beat in your desired amount of food coloring just until combined. I use 1-2 teaspoons gel food coloring. Vigorously whisk or beat the 4\u00a0egg whites on high speed until fluffy peaks form as pictured above, about 3 minutes. Gently fold into cake batter. The batter will be\u00a0silky and slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide batter between cake pans. Bake for 30-32\u00a0minutes or until the tops of the cakes spring back\u00a0when gently touched\u00a0and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. If the cakes need a little longer as determined by wet crumbs on the toothpick, bake for longer. However, careful not to overbake as the cakes\u00a0may dry out. Remove cakes from the oven and cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium-high speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar, vanilla extract, and a pinch of salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 3 minutes until completely combined and creamy. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin or an extra pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Frosting should be soft, but not runny.", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a large serrated knife,\u00a0slice\u00a0a thin layer off the tops of the cakes\u00a0to create a flat surface. Discard or crumble over finished cake. Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with frosting. Top with 2nd layer and spread remaining frosting all over the top and sides. I always use an icing spatula and bench scraper for the frosting. I used Wilton piping tip #12 for decoration around the top.", "name": "Assemble and frost", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-layer-cake-with-cream-cheese-frosting/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate cake for at least 30-60 minutes before slicing. I have done Red Velvet Cake the past years for my Birthdays and it always went somewhat wrong with the cake collapsing. Through this recipe I realised that I had not let them cool down properly before taking them out of the pan. This worked magic. The cake was so darn delicious, moist and soft. The only thing that didn't work out was the frosting. I'm not sure if the metric measuring is a bit off but it was waaay too much confectioners sugar. The Icing was totally runny and I had to add a lot more Cream Cheese to balance it out. Could also have something to do with the Cream Cheese in Switzerland being different than US Cream Cheese? Eitherway, apart from that. Excellent Recipe. I will definitely redo that recipe."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Vivian Howell"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-24", "reviewBody": "The cake was superb. This cookie dough\u00a0must be chilled, so plan accordingly.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cherry almond shortbread cookies, cherry almond shortbread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Cherry-Almond-Shortbread-Cookies-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Cherry-Almond-Shortbread-Cookies-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Cherry-Almond-Shortbread-Cookies-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Cherry-Almond-Shortbread-Cookies-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-almond-shortbread-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2/3 cup (134g) granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon almond extract", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) maraschino cherry juice", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "16 maraschino cherries (drained and chopped)", "optional: 4 ounces white chocolate"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on high speed until creamy, about 1 minute. Switch mixer to medium speed and add the the sugar, vanilla and almond extracts.\u00a0Scrape down the sides and the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer running on high, slowly drizzle in 1 Tablespoon of the cherry juice. Beat for 1 minute on high. Turn the mixer off and pour the flour into the wet ingredients.\u00a0Turn the mixer on low and slowly beat until a very soft dough is formed, then, with the mixer still running on low, add the chopped cherries. Beat just until the cherries are disbursed in the dough. Press the dough down to compact it\u00a0and tightly cover with plastic wrap to chill until firm, at least 4 hours (and up to 3 days). If the cookie dough is not sufficiently chilled, your cookies will spread.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-almond-shortbread-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line two baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats (silicone mats preferred to reduce spreading). Shape the cookie dough into balls. Mine were about 1 Tablespoon of dough per ball. Make sure they&#8217;re nice and smooth. If you find that the balls of dough are sticky and/or have gotten a little soft after rolling, place the balls of dough back into the refrigerator to firm up. You absolutely DO NOT want soft dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-almond-shortbread-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 11-12 minutes, or until very lightly browned on the edges. The cookies will puff up and spread slightly. Do not overbake. \u00a0In fact, I only baked mine for 10 minutes. I prefer them a little soft. Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack. Allow to cool for at least 30 minutes before drizzling with white chocolate. Melt the white chocolate in a double boiler or in the microwave, in 20 second increments, stirring after each increment until melted. I used a squeeze bottle to drizzle the melted white chocolate.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-almond-shortbread-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}], "prepTime": "PT4H15M", "cookTime": "PT11M", "totalTime": "PT5H15M", "recipeYield": ["24", "24 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "10", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Francine Platt"}, "datePublished": "2022-12-16", "reviewBody": "Another great recipe! \r\nThank you Sally!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Carrie H."}, "datePublished": "2022-12-19", "reviewBody": "These are SO pretty and one of my favorite cookies for Christmas cookie tray. The ingredients are exactly the same as when I originally published the recipe in 2017, but quartering *some* of the cherries instead of just halving and reducing some juices on the stovetop both guarantee that the pie filling will set up perfectly.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cherry pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/cherry-pie-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/cherry-pie-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/cherry-pie-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/cherry-pie-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["Homemade Pie Crust or All Butter Pie Crust (both recipes make 2 crusts, 1 for bottom and 1 for top)", "4 and 1/2 cups halved &amp; quartered pitted fresh cherries (see note)", "2/3\u00a0cup (135g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (28g) cornstarch", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) lemon juice", "1\u00a0teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/4 teaspoon almond extract", "1 Tablespoon (14g) cold unsalted butter, cut into small cubes", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional: coarse sugar for sprinkling on crust"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare either pie crust recipe through step 5. The pie dough needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before using.", "name": "The crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, stir the cherries, sugar, cornstarch, lemon juice, vanilla, and almond extract together until thoroughly combined. Cover the filling and place in the refrigerator as you roll out the pie dough (or for up to 24 hours).", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (keep the other one in the refrigerator). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the cherries into the crust. Reserve the juice in the bowl for the next step. Refrigerate pie, uncovered, as you reduce the juice in the next step.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the leftover juice into a small saucepan. Cook over low heat, stirring, until juice has slightly reduced and thickened, about 3\u20134 minutes. Cool for 5 minutes, then pour over cherries in filling. Do your best to gently toss together\u2014doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect. The reduction will harden and thicken as a result of mixing with the cold cherries\u2014this is normal. Dot the pieces of cold butter on top of the filling. Place the pie in the refrigerator while you roll out the top crust.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the other disc of pie dough from the refrigerator. Roll the dough into a circle 12 inches in diameter. Using a pastry wheel, sharp knife, or pizza cutter, cut the dough into strips\u2014for the pictured pie, I cut four strips 2 inches wide and four strips 1 inch wide. Carefully thread the strips over and under one another, pulling back strips as necessary to weave. See this post on How to Lattice Pie Crust for help with this step. Press the edges of the strips into the bottom pie crust edges to seal. Use kitchen shears or a small paring knife to trim off excess dough. Flute or crimp the pie crust edges.", "name": "Arrange\u00a0the lattice", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a pastry brush, lightly brush the top and edges of the pie crust with egg wash. Sprinkle the top with coarse sugar, if using. Place the pie in the refrigerator for 20\u201330 minutes while your oven preheats.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the pie onto a large baking sheet and bake for 20 minutes. Keeping the pie in the oven, reduce the temperature to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C) and bake for an additional 30\u201340 minutes or until the top crust is golden brown and the filling juices have been bubbling up around the edges or through the lattice/vents for at least 5 minutes. *After the first 20 minutes of bake time, I recommend placing a pie crust shield on the crust&#8217;s edges to prevent it from over-browning too quickly.*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pie from the oven, place on a cooling rack, and cool for at least 3\u20134 hours before slicing and serving. Filling will be too juicy if the pie is still warm when you slice it.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftovers tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cherry-pie/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT3H", "cookTime": "PT55M", "totalTime": "PT7H", "recipeYield": ["8", "8-10 servings"], "recipeCategory": "Pie", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "212", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Cherry Pie | Sally's Baking", "description": "This homemade cherry pie is perfectly sliceable with a thick almond-hinted cherry pie filling and a golden brown buttery flaky pie crust. This takes at least 5 minutes of cutting in with a pastry cutter.", "name": "Make the crumble mixture for the crust and topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-strawberry-crumb-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg, egg yolk, brown sugar, and vanilla together in a small bowl. Pour over the flour/butter mixture and gently mix together until the mixture resembles moist crumbly sand. Use your hands if needed\u2014the mixture comes together easier with your hands than with a spoon. I thought about a similar recipe by Nestle prior to making these for their chocolate crumb bars where they only use butter, granulated sugar and flour -NO EGG! Pretty much a shortbread recipe that tastes a whole lot better than this recipe with the 1 egg and egg yolk. I wondered before making how the egg would help the crust. I thought it would be a nice firm, crisp crust. It was not. Also there is not nearly enough sugar in the crust. If I were to make these again I would totally skip the egg and just use the flour, butter and sugar. The baking powder and vanilla extract also really was not needed. As these ingredients did not add any \u201crise or additional flavor. Second, I\u2019d pre bake the crust for at least 15 mins at 350. I would also add MORE sugar to sweeten then mash my berries and cook just a bit to develop the flavor. I\u2019d then allow the crust and filling to cool a bit and then proceed to assemble these again crust dish then bake it for the final product. There wouldn\u2019t be a soggy, tasteless, crust with berries that were barely cooked or sweetened. Now I\u2019m hoping to salvage this by adding the glaze. If not, I\u2019ll have to toss it. It\u2019s that bad and I hate it because again, I\u2019ve loved and sworn by all your other recipes. Oh well. I made this with only 3 cups of strawberries because that's what I had left from my haul at the strawberry farm.  Based on other reviews I mixed the strawberry mixture up first and then I spooned it onto the bottom crust with a slotted spoon to drain off some of the liquid.  Next time I'd probably mix the strawberries with the sugar first, then drain some juice, and then mix with cornstarch since I likely lost most of the cornstarch the way that I did it.  When it first cooled enough to eat I thought they were pretty good but could see where it needed the extra cup of strawberries.  But once they were fully cooled I don't know that I'd go with a full 4 cups next time either.  I can definitely see where they'd get soggy quickly so I'll probably pop them in a freezer and take them out a few at a time."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sarah R."}, "datePublished": "2022-07-09", "reviewBody": "I made these to take to the pool and they were a big hit! I got many compliments from my friends and people went back for seconds. I followed the recipe as written, but I mixed up the strawberry filling right before I poured it over the base, so there wasn't time for them to release their juices with the sugar. I didn't have any issues with sogginess, but I will probably bake them a touch longer next time. I erred closer to 40 minutes since the top was browning, but I think the base could have used a few more minutes. Thanks for another great recipe!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mari D"}, "datePublished": "2023-05-01", "reviewBody": "One of the best recipes I've ever made my boyfriend loved them so much! With a medium-large egg, this was too much liquid and turned the crumble into a goo. I felt like I couldn\u2019t save it so I just baked it. It still tasted good but I wouldn\u2019t make this again with that ratio bc it was blobby."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Siobh\u00e1n"}, "datePublished": "2024-03-02", "reviewBody": "Loved this recipe! I made it for people at work and the tray was gone in half an hour and 5 people asked for the recipe. I did the whole egg version and used the zest from a whole lemon instead of 1 tsp. 10/10 would make again"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Elisabeth D"}, "datePublished": "2024-04-15", "reviewBody": "My finished product was five stars, but the recipe itself was four stars because of all the changes that needed to be made. I read every single review and this is the recipe I came up with based on all the other reviews! I was hesitant to see how it would come out but it was perfect, so thank you to all the other reviewers!\r\n\r\n3 cups all-purpose flour\r\n1 teaspoon baking powder\r\n1 1/4 teaspoon salt\r\n1 cup unsalted butter, very cold and cubed\r\n4 tablespoons milk\r\n1 large egg, beat\r\n1 cup packed brown sugar\r\n2 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract\r\n4 cups (2 pounds) chopped strawberries\r\n1/3 cup granulated sugar\r\n1 and 1/2 Tablespoons cornstarch\r\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\r\n\r\nSteps:\r\n1. As soon as the strawberries are chopped, place them in a medium bowl and stir in the granulated sugar. Let sit until needed (to draw out juices that would make bars soggy).\r\n2. Mix flour, baking powder and salt in large bowl, then cut in cubed butter (I placed in food processor and pulsed it a few seconds). \r\n3. Mix brown sugar, egg, vanilla extract and milk in a small bowl\r\n4. Pour wet mixture into dry mixture and stir with fork and hands as needed until you\u2019re able to snap My finished product was five stars, but the recipe itself was four stars because of all the changes that needed to be made. I read every single review and this is the recipe I came up with based on all the other reviews! I was hesitant to see how it would come out but it was perfect, so thank you to all the other reviewers!\r\n\r\n3 cups all-purpose flour\r\n1 teaspoon baking powder\r\n1 1/4 teaspoon salt\r\n1 cup unsalted butter, very cold and cubed\r\n4 tablespoons milk\r\n1 large egg, beat\r\n1 cup packed brown sugar\r\n2 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract\r\n4 cups (2 pounds) chopped strawberries\r\n1/3 cup granulated sugar\r\n1 and 1/2 Tablespoons cornstarch\r\n1 teaspoon lemon zest\r\n\r\nSteps:\r\n1. As soon as the strawberries are chopped, place them in a medium bowl and stir in the granulated sugar. Let sit until needed (to draw out juices that would make bars soggy).\r\n2. Mix flour, baking powder and salt in large bowl, then cut in cubed butter (I placed in food processor and pulsed it a few seconds). \r\n3. Mix brown sugar, egg, vanilla extract and milk in a small bowl\r\n4. Pour wet mixture into dry mixture and stir with fork and hands as needed until you\u2019re able to shape dough onto bottom of pan without too many crumbles. \r\n5. Use a slotted spoon to scoop out berries from the released juices (I had about 1/2 cup of juice). Stir in lemon zest and corn starch. \r\n6. Press 2/3 (about 4 cups) crumbles down into a 9x13 glass baking dish, lined with parchment paper. Once shaped, spread strawberry mixture evenly, then sprinkle remaining crumble mixture. I used the back of a measuring cup to press down. \r\n7. Bake in 350\u00b0 oven for 45-55 minutes until lightly browned and bubbly. Let cool completely. \r\n8. Make glaze with 1 cup of powdered sugar and about 2 tablespoons lemon juice. (I made sure mine was just wet enough to spread, but not too runny.) When bars have cooled, spoon glaze over and spread evenly. Let glaze set before slicing and serving. Pairs very well with vanilla ice cream!\r\n\r\nThis was a hit all around and had the perfect flavor without being too sweet, just enough crumbles without being dry, and moist enough without being cakey and soggy. I hope this helps someone!!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lauren Mathis"}, "datePublished": "2025-02-26", "reviewBody": "Absolutely delicious! \r\n\r\nI followed the recipe exactly as written, and they came out amazingly well! I had one to taste, and split some for my kids, and we all loved them. Taking the rest to a group dinner tonight, and I can\u2019t imagine they won\u2019t be a hit. \r\n\r\nI\u2019m not sure what happened with others based on the number of \u201cmeh\u201d reviews, but these turned out so great for me!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Bill Smith"}, "datePublished": "2025-03-31", "reviewBody": "Recipe came out great! Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/1-bowl-white-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a microwave-safe bowl, combine the butter and chopped\u00a0white\u00a0chocolate. Melt in 30 second increments, whisking\u00a0after each, until completely smooth. Whisk in the sugar until completely combined, then whisk in the eggs and vanilla. Whisk\u00a0in the flour and salt, then fold in the white chocolate chips until combined. Batter will be thick.\u00a0Spread evenly into prepared pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/1-bowl-white-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 30 minutes, covering loosely with aluminum foil halfway through. Test the brownies with a toothpick at the 30 minute mark. Insert it into the center of the pan. If it comes out with wet batter, the brownies are not done. If there are only a few moist crumbs, the brownies are done. Keep checking every 2 minutes until you have moist crumbs. My brownies take 32\u00a0minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/1-bowl-white-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and place on a wire rack to cool completely before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/1-bowl-white-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In a large\u00a0bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on high\u00a0speed until smooth and creamy. The candy cane crunch and white chocolate put them over the top!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peppermint mocha cookies, mocha cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/peppermint-mocha-cookies-recipe-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/peppermint-mocha-cookies-recipe-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/peppermint-mocha-cookies-recipe-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/peppermint-mocha-cookies-recipe.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) packed\u00a0light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon peppermint extract", "1 cup (125g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 cup + 2 Tablespoons (51g) unsweetened natural cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "2 teaspoons espresso powder or 1 Tablespoon instant coffee granules", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "1\u00a0cup (180g) mini or regular size semi-sweet chocolate chips", "8 ounces white chocolate, coarsely chopped", "3 large candy canes, crushed"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar together on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color, about 2-3 minutes. Add the egg, vanilla extract, and peppermint extract, and then beat on high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl, whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, espresso powder, and salt together until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly pour into the wet ingredients. Beat on low until combined and then beat in the chocolate chips. The cookie dough will be thick and very sticky. Cover dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this sticky cookie dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 10 minutes. If the cookie dough chilled longer than 3 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 20 minutes. This makes the chilled cookie dough easier to scoop and roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. (Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop and roll dough, 1.5 Tablespoons of dough each, into balls. A medium cookie scoop is helpful for this step. To ensure a thicker cookie, make the balls taller than they are wide (almost like a cylinder or column). Arrange 2-3 inches apart on the baking sheets. The cookie dough is certainly sticky, so wipe your hands clean after every few balls of dough you shape.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 11-12 minutes or until the edges appear set and the centers still look soft. Tip: If they aren\u2019t really spreading by minute 9, remove them from the oven and lightly bang the baking sheet on the counter 2-3x. This helps initiate that spread. Return to the oven to continue baking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool cookies for 5 minutes on the baking sheet, and then transfer to a cooling rack to cool completely. The cookies will slightly deflate as they cool.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped white chocolate in a double boiler or use the microwave. For the microwave, place the white chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. Melt in 15 second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Dip each completely cooled cookie halfway into the white chocolate and place onto a parchment or silicone baking mat-lined baking sheet. Sprinkle crushed candy canes on top of the chocolate. Repeat with the rest of the cooled cookies. Place the baking sheet into the refrigerator to help the chocolate set, about 1 hour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT3H30M", "cookTime": "PT11M", "totalTime": "PT4H30M", "recipeYield": ["20", "20-22 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "39", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Peppermint Mocha Cookies | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "These peppermint mocha cookies are soft-baked with a generous dunk in white chocolate and sprinkle of candy cane crunch. They're shaped like cinnamon rolls, but taste like flaky chocolate babka. You can make the chocolate rolls within a few hours or get started the night before using the overnight preparation option.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate sweet rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/chocolate-sweet-rolls-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/chocolate-sweet-rolls-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/chocolate-sweet-rolls-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/chocolate-sweet-rolls.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup\u00a0(240ml)\u00a0whole milk, warmed to about 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C)", "6 Tablespoons (75g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 Tablespoon (9g) active dry or instant yeast", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon salt", "4 cups (530g) bread flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for hands/work surface", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup\u00a0(100g)\u00a0packed light or dark brown sugar", "2 Tablespoons (10g) unsweetened natural or dutch process cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3/4 cup (135g) semi-sweet chocolate chips or a 4 ounce semi-sweet chocolate bar, finely chopped*", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) heavy cream*", "1 teaspoon espresso powder*", "1 and 1/2 cups (180g)\u00a0confectioners\u2019 sugar, sifted (sift after measuring)", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Whisk the warm milk, 2 Tablespoons sugar, and the yeast together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining sugar, the butter, eggs, salt, and 1 cup (about 130g) of flour and beat on medium speed for 1 minute. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula. Add 3 cups (about 400g)  flour, switch the mixer down to low speed, and beat until a soft dough forms and pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Dough will be very soft, but not overly sticky. Beat in 2-3 more Tablespoons of flour if dough seems very sticky. Avoid adding more flour than you need.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 6-8 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6-8 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to\u00a0Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a metal or glass 9\u00d713-inch baking dish or line with parchment paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll dough into a 10\u00d716-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you\u2019re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix all of the filling ingredients together except for the chopped chocolate/chocolate chips. The softer the butter is, the easier it is to mix. (Microwave it for a few seconds to soften if needed.) Spread mixture all over the dough. Sprinkle chopped chocolate/chocolate chips evenly on top. Tightly roll up the dough to form a 16-inch-long log. If some filling spills out, sprinkle it on top of the roll. With an extra sharp knife, cut into 12 even rolls, between 1-1.5 inches each. Arrange in the prepared baking pan.", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until doubled in size, about 1 hour. (Or use the overnight option below.)", "name": "2nd Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake rolls for about 25-28 minutes or until they are lightly browned on top. After about 15 minutes, tent a piece of aluminum foil over the top of the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly and baking unevenly. Remove pan from the oven and place pan on a wire rack for about 10 minutes as you make the icing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Warm the cream on the stove until barely simmering or warm it in the microwave for 15-30 seconds. Whisk espresso powder into the warm cream, then whisk in the confectioners&#8217; sugar and vanilla extract until combined. Drizzle the icing over the warm rolls and serve immediately.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover frosted or unfrosted rolls tightly and store at room temperature for up to 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT28M", "totalTime": "PT4H30M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 rolls"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "288", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Chocolate Sweet Rolls | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "These outrageously rich and indulgent chocolate sweet rolls come together with a buttery soft fresh homemade dough and brown sugar chocolate filling. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, strawberry powder, heavy cream/milk, and vanilla. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then switch to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. Taste. Add 1\u20132 more Tablespoons of heavy cream/milk if needed to thin out, if desired. (I usually add at least 1 more.) Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-frosting/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use immediately or cover tightly and store for up to 1 week in the refrigerator or up to 3 months in the freezer. After thawing or refrigerating, beating in a splash of heavy cream or milk will help thin the frosting out again, if needed. Your new favorite cake for the crisp fall weather.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple bundt cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/apple-bundt-cake-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/apple-bundt-cake-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/apple-bundt-cake-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/apple-bundt-cake-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-apple-bundt-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "3\u00a0teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 and 1/4 cups (300ml) vegetable oil", "1/2 cup (120g) plain yogurt or sour cream, at room temperature", "1 and 1/4 cups (250g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract (yes, 1 full Tablespoon)", "3 cups (360g) peeled and chopped apples, about 2\u20133 large apples\u00a0", "1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter", "1/2 cup (120ml) heavy cream", "1/2 cup (60g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, sifted"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C). Spray a 10-to-12-cup Bundt pan with nonstick spray. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-apple-bundt-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt together in a large bowl until combined. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the oil, yogurt, brown sugar, granulated sugar, eggs, and vanilla together until combined and creamy. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and slowly whisk until no large lumps remain. Try to avoid over-mixing. Carefully fold in the apple chunks. If you feel 3 large apples is too much, feel free to cut down to 2 apples. I like a lot of apple chunks in my cake!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-apple-bundt-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon/pour the thick batter into the prepared bundt pan. Bake for 55\u201375 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the cake comes out clean. The baking times may vary depending on your oven, if you used a 10 cup bundt pan or 12 cup, or if you used less apple chunks. Keep your eye on the cake after 55 minutes. Feel free to cover the cake loosely with aluminum foil about halfway through to prevent heavy browning on top. Allow the cake to cool in the pan set on a wire rack, then invert onto a serving plate once cooled and ready to serve.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-apple-bundt-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the cake cools, prepare the brown sugar glaze. Combine the butter, brown sugar, and heavy cream in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Stir constantly until the butter has melted, and then stop stirring and let the mixture come to a rapid boil. Boil for 1 minute. Turn the heat down to low, give it a quick stir, and let simmer for 1 minute. Remove from heat and whisk in the sifted confectioners\u2019 sugar. Allow glaze to cool and slightly thicken for at least 10 minutes. Spoon glaze over the cake right before serving. (Cake can still be warm when glazing.) If your glaze thickened up too much as it cooled, warm in the microwave for 15 seconds and stir until smooth.", "name": "Make the glaze", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-apple-bundt-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I like this cake warm, at room temperature, and even cold. Cover\u00a0leftovers and store at room temperature for 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days. Flavor is outstanding on day 2!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-apple-bundt-cake/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT2H30M", "recipeYield": ["10", "serves 10-12"], "recipeCategory": "Cake", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "103", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Leah"}, "datePublished": "2025-09-28", "reviewBody": "this is perfection! Review recipe notes before starting and don't forget to check out the step-by-step crust photos below the recipe.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pumpkin tart", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/pumpkin-tart-with-homemade-whipped-cream-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/pumpkin-tart-with-homemade-whipped-cream-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/pumpkin-tart-with-homemade-whipped-cream-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/pumpkin-tart-with-homemade-whipped-cream-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spiced-pumpkin-tart/", "recipeIngredient": ["2/3 cup (85g) chopped or halved pecans", "1 and 1/4 cups\u00a0(160g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "1/4 cup (60ml) ice cold water", "1 and 1/3 cups (300g) pumpkin puree*", "3/4 cup\u00a0(150g) packed light or dark\u00a0brown sugar", "3/4 cup (180ml)\u00a0heavy cream", "1\u00a0large\u00a0egg", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1 and 1/4 teaspoon\u00a0ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0ground ginger", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0ground\u00a0nutmeg", "1/8 teaspoon\u00a0ground cloves", "pinch black pepper (see note)", "whipped cream, salted caramel, pepitas, pecans"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C). Place large baking sheet on center oven rack. You will bake the tart on the baking sheet, which will make it easy to transfer the tart pan to/from the oven AND catch any possible butter leakage from the tart pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spiced-pumpkin-tart/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you need a visual for the crust steps, there are helpful step-by-step photos below the recipe. Using a food processor, pulse the pecans, flour, salt, and sugar together until it reaches the consistency of coarse meal. Add the cubes of cold butter and pulse until the mixture forms pea-sized crumbs. Drizzle ice water on top and pulse 8-10 times to bring dough together.\u00a0 Dough will be crumbly, but there should be no more dry flour. Do your best to press dough tightly and evenly into the bottom and up the sides of a 9-inch tart pan. Carefully line the inside of the crust with two pieces of parchment paper. Pour in the pie weights. Make sure the weights are evenly distributed around the pan.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spiced-pumpkin-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place on baking sheet and bake (with weights) for 15 minutes. Remove tart from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper (with the weights) out of the tart. Prick holes all around the bottom crust with a fork. Return the tart crust to the oven (on the baking sheet) and bake for 10-12 minutes to help dry out and set the bottom. Remove from the oven and set aside until step 6. You can par-bake the crust up to 3 days ahead of time. Cover and store in the refrigerator (without weights) until ready to use.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spiced-pumpkin-tart/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Reduce oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spiced-pumpkin-tart/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk all of the filling ingredients together until combined and smooth. Much easier recipe to use than the oatmeal cups because thick batter is easy to portion out. Almond with skins as a nut flour worked. I increased the flour to 75g* because I added 15ml lemon juice = 1/2 lemon juiced (plus lemon zest, lemon yoghurt). The raw batter wasn't sweet so i added 2tbsp/25g sugar (120g 1 1/4 cups sugar in total using maple syrup and granulated sugar) and the cooked muffins taste lightly sweetened so I'm glad I checked first, because that would have been disappointing! Follow 12 muffins not \"filled to the top\" = 11 muffins with mushroom tops (yes they rose!). 20 minutes cook time was fine. Greasing the tin worked but they're hard to release without cutting into the muffins. Lightbulb moment - grease the tin and use strips of baking paper in a cross to give something to grip. With sugar to taste, and the tin issue worked out, I'll make them again."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mads"}, "datePublished": "2024-08-22", "reviewBody": "These are so good! Feel free to use other chocolate candies such as Rolos, peanut butter cups, or other small chocolates.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "red velvet, blossom cookies, red velvet cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/red-velvet-cookies-with-hersheys-kisses-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/red-velvet-cookies-with-hersheys-kisses-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/red-velvet-cookies-with-hersheys-kisses-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/red-velvet-cookies-with-hersheys-kisses.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 3/4 cups (219g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 cup (21g) natural unsweetened\u00a0cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 Tablespoon milk (I use buttermilk)", "1/2 teaspoon gel red food coloring (or alternative)*", "32-36 Hershey&#8217;s Kisses, unwrapped", "1/2 cup granulated sugar (100g) or confectioners&#8217; sugar (60g)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium speed until creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and vanilla extract and mix on high until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients, add the milk and food coloring, and then mix on low speed until everything is combined. The dough will be sticky. If you want a more vibrant hue, beat in more food coloring a little at a time. Cover and chill the dough in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours (and up to 3 days). If chilling for longer than a few hours, allow dough to sit at room temperature for at least 15 minutes before rolling and baking because the dough will be quite hard.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside. Also, make sure there&#8217;s room in your freezer because the cookies will need to be placed inside to prevent the chocolates from melting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop and roll cookie dough, about 1 Tablespoon of dough each. Roll each ball in the 1/2 cup of sugar and arrange on the baking sheet about 3 inches apart.", "name": "Roll &amp; coat", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 11-13 minutes or until the edges appear set. Centers will look very soft. Mine usually take 12 minutes. Add the granulated sugar and beat on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color. Beat in egg and vanilla on high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in the food coloring until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly mix the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until combined. The red velvet dough will be quite thick and sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-seven-layer-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a silicone spatula, spread dough in an even layer into the prepared baking pan. Here's how to make adorable snowman sugar cookies for your holiday cookie trays.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Snowman Sugar Cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/snowmen-sugar-cookies-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/snowmen-sugar-cookies-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/snowmen-sugar-cookies-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/snowmen-sugar-cookies-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/4 cups (281g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for rolling and work surface", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted\u00a0butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/4 or 1/2 teaspoon\u00a0almond extract\u00a0(optional, but makes the flavor outstanding)*", "Royal Icing", "red, black, and orange gel food coloring"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the egg, vanilla, and almond extract (if using) and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be a bit soft. If the dough seems too soft and sticky for rolling, add 1 more Tablespoon of flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Place each portion onto a piece of lightly floured parchment paper or a lightly floured silicone baking mat. With a lightly floured rolling pin, roll the dough out to about 1/4-inch thickness. Use more flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4-inch thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with flour. Place a piece of parchment on top. (This prevents sticking.) Place the 2nd rolled-out dough on top. Cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours and up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, preheat oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it&#8217;s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it. Using a snowman cookie cutter, cut into shapes. Re-roll the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with 2nd\u00a0dough piece of dough.\u00a0(Note: It doesn&#8217;t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Bake for 11-12 minutes, until lightly browned around the edges. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheet halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before\u00a0decorating.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare Royal Icing.\u00a0You&#8217;ll need 3 small bowls: one for red icing, one for black icing, and one for orange icing. Spoon 1/4 cup of icing into each bowl. The rest of the icing will remain white. Stir red food coloring into 1 bowl until you reach your desired shade. Stir black food coloring into another bowl until you reach your desired shade. (I find that black always dries darker so stop adding coloring when you reach a dark gray.) Finally, stir orange food coloring into the last bowl until you reach your desired shade.", "name": "Decorate:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fit a piping bag (reusable or disposable) with\u00a0Wilton piping tip #5 or piping tip #4. If you only have 1 of these piping tips, keep the tip on the outside of the bag by using a coupler so you can easily transfer the piping tip to the bag of red icing because you need the same tip for the red scarf. Spoon white icing inside the piping bag. Decorate cookies with white icing by piping a border around the edges and then filling it. (Leave room for the black hat!) Allow to set. I put the baking sheet in the refrigerator to speed it up.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, fill more piping bags with remaining colors of icing. You need Wilton piping tip #1 for the black hat, eyes, mouth, and button. You also need it for the orange icing, so if you only have 1 tip, use a\u00a0coupler so you can easily transfer the piping tip to the bag of orange icing. You need\u00a0Wilton piping tip #5 or piping tip #4 for the red scarf.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snowman-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the white icing sets, pipe the scarf with red icing. Plain or decorated cookies stay soft for about 5 days when covered tightly at room temperature. If you'd like to make dozens of cookies for a large crowd, double the recipe.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate sugar cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/chocolate-sugar-cookies-1-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/chocolate-sugar-cookies-1-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/chocolate-sugar-cookies-1-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/chocolate-sugar-cookies-1.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 cup (62g) unsweetened natural or dutch process cocoa powder, plus more as needed for rolling and work surface", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "Royal Icing\u00a0or\u00a0Easy Glaze Icing (royal icing is pictured)", "Assorted sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes.\u00a0Add the egg and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be soft. If the dough seems too soft and sticky for rolling, add 1 more Tablespoon of flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Dust 2 large pieces of parchment paper or 2 silicone baking mats with cocoa powder or flour. Place a dough half on each. With a rolling pin lightly dusted with cocoa powder or flour, roll the dough out to about 1/4-inch thickness. Use more cocoa powder/flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4-inch thick.", "name": "Roll the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with cocoa powder or flour. Place a piece of parchment on top. (This prevents sticking.) Place the 2nd rolled-out dough on top. Cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours and up to 2 days.", "name": "Chill the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2-3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. Using cookie cutters, cut the dough into shapes. Re-roll the remaining dough, using more cocoa powder or flour to lightly dust your work surface and rolling pin, and continue cutting the dough until all is used. Work quickly so the dough doesn&#8217;t become too warm or soft. If it does, stop what you&#8217;re doing and place any unused dough back in the refrigerator for 10 minutes to stiffen up again. Repeat cutting into shapes with 2nd half of dough. (Note: It doesn\u2019t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.)", "name": "Preheat oven &amp; shape cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange shaped cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Bake for 11-12 minutes or until edges are set. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheet halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes and then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before decorating.", "name": "Bake &amp; cool", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare the royal icing or cookie icing and decorate the cooled cookies however you&#8217;d like. Add sprinkles on top of the icing if desired. Feel free to tint either icing with gel food coloring. See post above for recommended decorating tools. No need to cover the decorated cookies as you wait for the icing to set. If it&#8217;s helpful, decorate the cookies directly on a baking sheet so you can stick the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator to help speed up the icing setting.", "name": "Make either icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Enjoy cookies right away or wait until the icing sets to serve them. Once the icing has set, these cookies are great for gifting or for sending. Plain or decorated cookies stay soft for about 5 days when covered tightly at room temperature. For longer storage, cover and refrigerate for up to 10 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT2H", "cookTime": "PT12M", "totalTime": "PT3H30M", "recipeYield": ["24", "24 3-4 inch cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "44", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Chocolate Sugar Cookies | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "These chocolate sugar cookies boast wonderful chocolate flavor, thick centers, crisp edges, and have plenty of room for decorating icing! Review recipe instructions and notes before beginning and use your favorite cheddar cheese.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cheese, apple pie, Thanksgiving", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/cheddar-apple-pie-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/cheddar-apple-pie-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/cheddar-apple-pie-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/cheddar-apple-pie-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour, plus more as needed\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, chilled and cubed", "1/2 cup (120ml) ice water, plus more as needed", "1 cup (4 ounces) freshly shredded cheddar cheese*", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional: coarse sugar for sprinkling on crust", "8 large apples, cored, peeled, and sliced into 1/4-inch slices (10 cups, or 1250g, total)*", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (31g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon each: ground allspice, ground cloves, &amp; ground nutmeg", "1/3 cup freshly shredded cheddar cheese*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the flour, sugar, and salt together in a large bowl. Add the cubed butter on top. Using a pastry cutter, food processor, or 2 forks (pastry cutter is ideal, see post above), cut the butter into the dry ingredients until all flour is coated. You&#8217;re looking for pea-sized bits of flour-coated butter. A few larger bits of butter is OK.", "name": "Make the pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Measure 1/2 cup (120ml) of water in a cup. Add ice. Stir it around. From that, measure 1/2 cup (120ml) of water since the ice has melted a bit. Drizzle the cold water in, 2 Tablespoons (30ml) at a time, and stir after each addition. Stop adding water when the dough comes together easily and begins to form large clumps. The dough will feel moist and a little sticky, but not overly wet. Do not add any more water than you need to. I always use about 1/2 cup (120ml) of ice water. Using a silicone spatula, carefully fold in the cheese. Avoid overworking the dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place pie dough on a lightly floured work surface. Using floured hands, fold the dough into itself until the flour is fully incorporated into the fats. Form it into a ball. Cut dough in half. Using your hands, flatten each half into a 1-inch thick disc. Wrap each disc tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours and up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, stir the apple slices, sugar, flour, cinnamon, allspice, cloves, nutmeg, and 1/3 cup cheese together until thoroughly combined. Set filling aside as you roll out the pie crust.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (keep the other one in the refrigerator). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Smooth out the edges with your fingers if you notice cracks. Keeping your work surface, rolling pin, and hands lightly floured makes rolling out easier. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. You can watch me do this at the :43 mark in my pecan praline pumpkin pie video. (Also, for a nice thick edge, I usually don&#8217;t trim the overhanging dough from the edges of the crust. Instead, fold the excess dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a nice thick rim around the pie. You can do this before or after you add the top pie crust.)", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the filling into the crust.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll out the 2nd pie crust just like you rolled out the bottom pie crust. You can simply lay the pie crust on top of the filling to make a double crust pie (slit a few holes in the top for air vents) or you can create a pretty pie crust design on top like a lattice pie crust and/or a braided pie crust. Crimp the edges with a fork or flute the edges with your fingers. (Review my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial if you need extra help with this step.) Brush the pie crust with egg wash. Sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired. This adds a lovely sweet crunch.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). The colder the pie dough, the more likely it will hold its beautiful shape.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the pie onto a large baking sheet and bake for 25 minutes. Keeping the pie in the oven, turn the temperature down to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C) and bake for an additional 30\u201335 minutes. After the first 20 minutes of bake time, I place a pie crust shield on top of the pie to prevent the edges from browning too quickly.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cheddar-pie/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool for at least 3 full hours at room temperature before serving. It&#8217;s important that white fudge is the base of the fudge!) Pour some gingerbread fudge on top, followed by more white fudge, more gingerbread fudge, etc until everything is used up. Fun to make, beautiful to serve, and packed with flavor in every bite.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "spumoni cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/spumoni-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/spumoni-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/spumoni-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/spumoni-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 large egg yolk, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/4 cup (50g) maraschino cherries, drained, patted very dry, and finely chopped", "3 Tablespoons (24g) all-purpose flour", "optional: 1 tiny drop pink gel food coloring (I did not use in the pictured cookies)", "1/2 cup (55g) ground pistachios (salted or unsalted)", "1/4 teaspoon almond extract", "optional: 1 tiny drop green gel food coloring", "2 Tablespoons (10g) Dutch-process cocoa powder", "2 teaspoons maraschino cherry juice, from the jar", "1/3 cup (60g) mini chocolate chips\u00a0", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.", "name": "Make the base cookie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#:1fo"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar together on medium-high speed until creamed, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract, and beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and beat on low speed until incorporated, then increase to medium-high speed and beat until fully combined. The dough will be thick. Divide it into 3 equal portions.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return one portion of dough to the mixing bowl. Add the chopped, blotted cherries, 3 Tablespoons flour, and pink gel food coloring (if using). Beat on medium speed until combined. Transfer the cherry dough to a bowl and refrigerate it while you prepare the remaining 2 doughs. Wipe the mixer bowl clean.", "name": "Make the cherry dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return another portion of dough to the mixing bowl. Add the ground pistachios, almond extract, and green gel food coloring (if using). Beat on medium speed until combined. Set aside. Wipe the mixer bowl clean.", "name": "Make the pistachio dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return the final portion of dough to the mixing bowl. Add the cocoa powder, cherry juice, and mini chocolate chips. Beat on medium speed until combined. Set aside.", "name": "Make the chocolate dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line baking sheets or large plates with parchment paper. Remove the cherry dough from the refrigerator. Scoop and roll it into small balls, about 15g each (a heaping 1/2 Tablespoon). Place on the lined baking sheet or plate, then refrigerate these cherry dough balls while you shape the pistachio and chocolate doughs. Repeat the shaping process with the pistachio and chocolate doughs, rolling all remaining dough into small balls, about 15g each.", "name": "Shape the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the granulated sugar for rolling in a small bowl or on a plate. Remove the cherry dough balls from the refrigerator/freezer. Press together 3 dough balls\u20141 of each flavor\u2014and roll them into a single 45g cookie dough ball. Roll each marbled dough ball in the granulated sugar, then place on a lined baking sheet. Once all cookies are shaped and coated, cover and refrigerate the dough balls for at least 1 hour before baking (or up to 3 days). Chilling the shaped dough balls is imperative.", "name": "Topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spumoni-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).
